sen.j: 田中 吉政（たなか よしまさ、天文 (元号)17年（1548年) - 慶長14年2月18日 (旧暦)（1609年3月23日))は、戦国時代 (日本)・安土桃山時代の武将、江戸時代の大名。
sen.e: Yoshimasa TANAKA (1548-March 23,1609) was a Japanese military commander in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and later, was a Japanese feudal lord in the Edo period.

Yoshimasa TANAKA (1548-March 23,1609) was a Japanese military commander in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and later, was a Japanese feudal lord in the Edo period.

Yoshimasa TANAKA (1548-March 23,1609) was a Japanese military commander in the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States) and the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and later, was a Japanese feudal lord in the Edo period.

sen.j: 転封の過程で居城とした近江国・八幡（現滋賀県近江八幡市)、三河国・岡崎（現愛知県岡崎市)、筑後国・柳河（現福岡県柳川市)などに、現在につながる都市設計を行った。
sen.e: He practiced city planning of Hachiman, Omi Province (present-day Omihachiman City, Shiga Prefecture); Okazaki, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture); Yanagawa, Chikugo Province (present-day Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) and others, where he was stationed, and it led to the present.

He practiced city planning in Hachiman, Omi Province (present-day Omihachiman City, Shiga Prefecture); Okazaki, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture); Yanagawa, Chikugo Province (present-day Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) and others, where he was stationed. His work can be seen today.

He practiced city planning, the idea of which can be seen today, in Hachiman, Omi Province (present-day Omihachiman City, Shiga Prefecture), Okazaki, Mikawa Province (present-day Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture), Yanagawa, Chikugo Province (present-day Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture) and others, where he was stationed.

sen.j: そのことは現代でも高く評価できる。
sen.e: It is highly regarded even in our time.
It is highly regarded even in our time.
It is highly regarded even in our time.

sen.j: 田中氏は、18世紀後半に編纂された『寛政重修諸家譜』によると近江国・高島郡田中村（現在の滋賀県高島市安曇川町田中)の出身であったという。
sen.e: According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu" (genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu) which was compiled in the latter half of the 18th century, the Tanaka clan was from Tanaka Village, Takashima District, Omi Province (present-day Tanaka, Adogawa Town, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu" (genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu) which was compiled in the latter half of the 18th century, the Tanaka clan was from Tanaka Village, Takashima District, Omi Province (present-day Tanaka, Adogawa Town, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu" (genealogies of vassals in Edo Bakufu) which was compiled in the latter half of the 18th century, the Tanaka clan was from Tanaka Village, Takashima District, Omi Province (present-day Tanaka, Adogawa Town, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

sen.j: また先祖は近江源氏高島氏の一族田中氏で田中城の城主であったともいわれる。
sen.e: And Yoshimasa TANAKA's ancestor was Tanaka family, which was a part of the Minamoto clan in Omi named Takashima clan, and is said to have been the lord of Tanaka-jo Castle.
And Yoshimasa TANAKA's ancestors were the Tanaka family, which was a part of the Minamoto clan in Omi named Takashima clan, and is said to have been the lord of Tanaka-jo Castle.
And Yoshimasa TANAKA's ancestors were the Tanaka family, which was a part of the Minamoto clan in Omi named Takashima clan, and is said to have been the lord of Tanaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 吉政が家紋に「一つ目結い」紋（釘抜き紋ともいう)をもちいたことから、先祖は佐々木氏となんらかの関係があったことは間違いないとされる。
sen.e: Judging from his family crest, "Hitotsumeyui-mon" (or "Kuginuki-mon"), it is certain that his ancestor had a relationship with the Sasaki clan.
Judging from his family crest, "Hitotsumeyui-mon" (or "Kuginuki-mon"), it is certain that his ancestors had a relationship with the Sasaki clan.

sen.cmt: 余分なスペースの削除

sen.j: 織田信長の高島郡進攻により田中氏は当時は帰農していたとされる。
sen.e: The Tanaka clan is said to have taken up farming again at that time, as a result of Nobunaga ODA's invasion of Takashima District.
The Tanaka clan is said to have taken up farming again at that time, as a result of Nobunaga ODA's invasion of Takashima District.
The Tanaka clan is said to have taken up farming again at that time, as a result of Nobunaga ODA's invasion of Takashima District.

sen.j: また吉政の出生地は浅井郡の三川村または宮部村（現在の東浅井郡虎姫町内)で、吉政自身はそこに住む農民であったという説もある。
sen.e: In another theory, his birth place was Mikawa Village or Miyabe Village, Asai District (present-day Torahime Town, Higashiazai District) and he was a peasant there.
In another theory, his birth place was Mikawa Village or Miyabe Village, Asai District (present-day Torahime Town, Higashiazai District) and he may have been a peasant there.
In another theory, his birth place was Mikawa Village or Miyabe Village, Asai District (present-day Torahime Town, Higashiazai District) and he may have been a peasant there.

sen.j: この根拠としては、浅井郡の住人に限られる竹生島の行事・蓮華会の頭人を柳川藩主となっていた吉政が担ったという記録があることである。
sen.e: The theory is based on a record which says that as the lord of Yanagawa Domain, Yoshimasa became a head of Rengee, which was only an Asai District residents' function in Chikubushima Island.
The theory is based on a record which says that as the lord of Yanagawa Domain, Yoshimasa became a head of Rengee, which was only an Asai District residents' function in Chikubushima Island.

sen.j: また三川村には田中吉政の出生伝承が残っている。
sen.e: And also, there is a tradition about Yoshimasa TANAKA's birth in Mikawa Village.
Also, there is a story about Yoshimasa TANAKA's birth in Mikawa Village.
Also, there is a story about Yoshimasa TANAKA's birth in Mikawa Village.

sen.j: 彼自身が宮部村の国人領主である宮部継潤に仕えた記録がある。
sen.e: A record says that he served the local samurai lord of Miyabe Village, Keijun MIYABE.
A record says that he served the local samurai lord of Miyabe Village, Keijun MIYABE.
A record says that he served the local samurai lord of Miyabe Village, Keijun MIYABE.

sen.j: また吉政の母すなわち国友与左衛門（宮部継潤家臣)の姉は宮部村と三川村にほど近い坂田郡国友村（当時有数の鉄砲の生産地。現在の長浜市国友町)の出身などである。
sen.e: Moreover, his mother, i.e. an older sister of Yozaemon KUNITOMO (a vassal of Keijun MIYABE) is said to have been from Kunitomo Village, Sakata District (a leading gun producing district at that time, present-day Kunitomo Town, Nagahama City) near Miyabe Village and Mikawa Village.

Moreover, his mother, i.e. an older sister of Yozaemon KUNITOMO (a vassal of Keijun MIYABE) is said to have been from Kunitomo Village, Sakata District (a leading gun producing district at that time, present-day Kunitomo Town, Nagahama City) near Miyabe Village and Mikawa Village.

Moreover, his mother, i.e. an older sister of Yozaemon KUNITOMO (a vassal of Keijun MIYABE) is said to have been from Kunitomo Village, Sakata District (a leading gun producing district at that time, present-day Kunitomo Town, Nagahama City) near Miyabe Village and Mikawa Village.

sen.j: ただ近江八幡時代以前の記録は少ない。
sen.e: However, there are few records of his times in Omihachiman and before.
However, there are few records of his times in Omihachiman and before.
However, there are few records of his times in Omihachiman and before.

tit.j: 近江八幡筆頭家老時代
tit.e: In the time of the head of chief vassals in Omihachiman
As the head of chief vassals in Omihachiman
As the head of chief vassals in Omihachiman

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年)ごろ宮部家中から、5000石を与えられ、秀吉の甥の羽柴秀次（のちの豊臣秀次)の宿老となった。
sen.e: In about 1582, he was given 5000 koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) by the Miyabe family and became a chief vassal of Hidetsugu HASHIBA (later Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI) who was a nephew of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

In about 1582, he was given 5000 koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) by the Miyabe family and became a chief vassal of Hidetsugu HASHIBA (later Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI) who was a nephew of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

In about 1582, he was given 5000 koku (a unit of volume: rice 1-koku is 180.39 liter) by the Miyabe family and became a chief vassal of Hidetsugu HASHIBA (later Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI) who was a nephew of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 天正13年（1585年)に秀次が近江八幡43万石を与えられると、吉政はその筆頭家老格となった。
sen.e: He became the head of sub-chief vassals when Hidetsugu was given 430,000 koku of Omihachiman in 1585.
He became the head of sub-chief vassals when Hidetsugu was given 430,000 koku of Omihachiman in 1585.
He became the head of sub-chief vassals when Hidetsugu was given 430,000 koku of Omihachiman in 1585.

sen.j: このとき、同じく秀次付き家老格となった中村一氏・堀尾吉晴・山内一豊・一柳直末らはそれぞれ居城を持ったが、吉政は秀次の居城・八幡山城にあって、関白殿一老として政務を取り仕切った。
sen.e: At that time, other Hidetsugu's attendant sub-chief vassals: Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Yoshiharu HORIO, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Naosue HITOTSUYANAGI, and others got their own castles, but Yoshimasa remained in Hidetsugu's Hachimanyama-jo Castle and administered affairs of the domain as the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro".

At that time, some of Hidetsugu's attendant sub-chief vassals: Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Yoshiharu HORIO, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Naosue HITOTSUYANAGI, and others got their own castles, but Yoshimasa remained in Hidetsugu's Hachimanyama-jo Castle and administered affairs of the domain in the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro".

At that time, some of Hidetsugu's attendant sub-chief vassals: Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Yoshiharu HORIO, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Naosue HITOTSUYANAGI, and others got their own castles, but Yoshimasa remained in Hidetsugu's Hachimanyama-jo Castle and administered affairs of the domain in the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro".

sen.j: また天正14年の大政所の三河下向にもかかわったという記述がある。
sen.e: There is a description that he was involved in Mikawa-geko (going to Mikawa Prefecture as a hostage) of Hideyoshi's mother in 1586.
There is a story that he was involved in Mikawa-geko (going to Mikawa Prefecture as a hostage) of Hideyoshi's mother in 1586.
There is a story that he was involved in Mikawa-geko (going to Mikawa Province as a hostage) of Hideyoshi's mother in 1586.

sen.j: この時代の吉政の書状は、比較的多く残っている。
sen.e: Most of Yoshimasa's letters from this time have been preserved and still exist today.
Most of Yoshimasa's letters from this time have been preserved and still exist today.
Most of Yoshimasa's letters from this time have been preserved and still exist today.

sen.j: 信長が築いた安土城城下の町を八幡城下に移し、町割を行った。
sen.e: He moved Azuchi-jo Castle town, built by Nobunaga, close to Yawata-jo Castle and headed the town's planning.
He moved Azuchi-jo Castle town, built by Nobunaga, close to Yawata-jo Castle and headed the town's planning.
He moved Azuchi-jo Castle town, built by Nobunaga, close to Yawata-jo Castle and headed the town's planning.

sen.j: 江戸時代中ごろまでは、久兵衛町と名づけられた地域が、近江八幡の町の一画に残っていた。
sen.e: There was an area named Kyube Town in Omihachiman town until the middle of the Edo period.
There was an area named Kyube Town in Omihachiman town until the middle of the Edo period.
There was an area named Kyube Town in Omihachiman town until the middle of the Edo period.

tit.e: In the time of Okazaki, Mikawa Province
In the time of Okazaki, Mikawa Province
In the time of Okazaki, Mikawa Province

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年)豊臣秀吉は関東の北条氏を制圧し、諸大名の大幅な配置換えを行った。
sen.e: In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ruled the Hojo clan of Kanto region and rearranged the positions of feudal lords greatly.
In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ruled the Hojo clan of Kanto region and rearranged the positions of feudal lords greatly.
In 1590, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ruled the Hojo clan of Kanto region and rearranged the positions of feudal lords greatly.

sen.j: この結果徳川家康は関東に転封された。
sen.e: As a result, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was moved to the Kanto region.
As a result, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was moved to the Kanto region.
As a result, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA was moved to the Kanto region.

sen.j: また織田信雄は下野国烏山2万石に減封された。
sen.e: And Nobukatsu ODA had his territory reduced to 20,000 koku of Karasuyama, Shimotsuke Province.
And Nobukatsu ODA had his territory reduced to 20,000 koku of Karasuyama, Shimotsuke Province.
And Nobukatsu ODA had his territory reduced to 20,000 koku of Karasuyama, Shimotsuke Province.

sen.j: その結果空いた尾張には豊臣秀次が入った。
sen.e: It led Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI to get Nobukatsu's now vacant former territory, Owari.
It led Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI to get Nobukatsu's now vacant former territory, Owari.
It led Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI to get Nobukatsu's now vacant former territory, Owari.

sen.j: 小田原攻めでも秀次軍として活躍した吉政は三河国岡崎城5万7400石の所領が与えられた。
sen.e: Yoshimasa was given 57,400 koku of Okazaki-jo Castle, Mikawa Province as a reward for his achievement in Hidetsugu's force during the Attack of Odawara.
Yoshimasa was given 57,400 koku of Okazaki-jo Castle, Mikawa Province as a reward for his achievement in Hidetsugu's force during the Attack of Odawara.
Yoshimasa was given 57,400 koku of Okazaki-jo Castle, Mikawa Province as a reward for his achievement in Hidetsugu's force during the Attack of Odawara.

sen.j: 尾張堤普請には惣奉行に命じられ、資材の調達にも関わっていた。
sen.e: He was appointed a chief of Bugyo (magistrate) and played a part in getting materials for construction of an embankment in Owari.
He was appointed a chief of Bugyo (magistrate) and played a part in getting materials for construction of an embankment in Owari.
He was appointed a chief of Bugyo (magistrate) and played a part in getting materials for construction of an embankment in Owari.

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年)、秀次は自害させられ、木村志摩守、前野景定、羽田正親、服部一忠、渡瀬繁詮、明石則実、一柳可遊、粟野秀用、白江成定、熊谷直之ら10名が賜死となり、そのほかにも多くの家臣が処分を受けた。
sen.e: In 1595, Hidetsugu was compelled to kill himself, and his ten vassals including the Governor of Shima Province named Kimura, Kagesada MAENO, Masachika HANEDA, Kazutada HATTORI, Shigeaki WATARASE, Norizane AKASHI, Kayu HITOTSUYANAGI, Hidemochi AWANO, Narisada SHIRAE, Naoyuki KUMAGAI got granted honorable deaths, and his other vassals were also punished; however chief vassals including he, Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Yoshiharu HORIO didn't get any punishment.

In 1595, Hidetsugu was compelled to kill himself, and his ten vassals including the Governor of Shima Province named KIMURA. Kagesada MAENO, Masachika HANEDA, Kazutada HATTORI, Shigeaki WATARASE, Norizane AKASHI, Kayu HITOTSUYANAGI, Hidemochi AWANO, Narisada SHIRAE, Naoyuki KUMAGAI were granted honorable deaths, and his other vassals were also punished. However, chief vassals including him, Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Yoshiharu HORIO didn't receive any punishment.

sen.j: しかし、田中吉政、中村一氏、山内一豊、堀尾吉晴ら宿老にはお咎めはなかった。
sen.e: However, chief vassals including him, Kazuuji NAKAMURA, Kazutoyo YAMAUCHI, Yoshiharu HORIO didn't receive any punishment.

sen.j: その際、石田三成が関与したかどうかは不明である。
sen.e: It's not certain that Mitsunari ISHIDA was involved in that decision.
It's not certain that Mitsunari ISHIDA was involved in that decision.
It's not certain that Mitsunari ISHIDA was involved in that decision.

sen.j: ただし、関白殿一老であった吉政に対しては、切腹を勧める者もいた。
sen.e: Some people proposed that he, who was in the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro", should have committed hara-kiri.
Some people proposed that he, who was in the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro", should have committed hara-kiri.
Some people proposed that he, who was in the position of "Kanpakudono-ichiro", should have committed seppuku (suicide by disembowelment).
sen.cmt: 用語統一リストにより、seppukuを採用。

sen.j: 吉政には実際は処分はなかった。
sen.e: In fact, he wasn't punished; on the contrary, he got an additional 28,358 koku 3 to (measure of volume, approx. 18 litres) as a reward for his remonstration with Hidetsugu.
In fact, he wasn't punished. On the contrary, he got an additional 28,358 koku 3 to (measure of volume, approx. 180 litres) as a reward for his remonstration with Hidetsugu.
In fact, he wasn't punished.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処☆原文を分割

sen.j: 「秀次によく諌言をした」ということで、吉政は2万8358石3斗の加増された。
sen.e: On the contrary, he got an additional 28,358 koku 3 to (measure of volume, approx. 18 litres) as a reward for his remonstration with Hidetsugu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処☆原文を分割180→18

sen.j: 文禄5年（1596年)に更に1万4252石6斗加増され、三河国岡崎城主、10万石の大名となった。
sen.e: Moreover, he got 14,252 koku 6 to and became the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle in Mikawa Province with 100,000 koku.
Moreover, he got 14,252 koku 6 to and became the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle in Mikawa Province with 100,000 koku.
Moreover, he got 14,252 koku 6 to and became the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle in Mikawa Province with 100,000 koku.

sen.j: 吉政は岡崎城を近世城郭に整備した。
sen.e: He made Okazaki-jo Castle modern.
He made Okazaki-jo Castle modern.
He made Okazaki-jo Castle modern.

sen.j: そして城下の町割には7つの町を堀で囲む田中掘を築造した。
sen.e: He built Tanaka Moat, which surrounded seven towns near his castle.
He built Tanaka Moat, which surrounded the seven towns near his castle.
He built Tanaka Moat, which surrounded the seven towns near his castle.

sen.j: また、西側の低湿地の埋め立てを行った。
sen.e: He also reclaimed wetlands on the west side.
He also reclaimed wetlands on the west side.
He also reclaimed wetlands on the west side.

sen.j: さらに、本来岡崎の郊外を通っていた東海道を岡崎城下町の中心を通るように変更し、「岡崎の27曲がり」といわれるクランク状の道に整備した。
sen.e: In addition, he changed the path of Tokai-do Road from within the suburbs of Okazaki to the middle of Okazaki-jo Castle town and improved it to a winding road called "27 curves road of Okazaki".
In addition, he changed the path of Tokai-do Road from within the suburbs of Okazaki to the middle of Okazaki-jo Castle town and improved it to a winding road called "27 curves road of Okazaki".
In addition, he changed the path of Tokai-do Road from within the suburbs of Okazaki to the middle of Okazaki-jo Castle town and improved it to a winding road called "27 curves road of Okazaki".

sen.j: 秀吉の死後は徳川家康に接近。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi's death, Yoshimasa approached Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
After Hideyoshi's death, Yoshimasa approached Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
After Hideyoshi's death, Yoshimasa approached Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年)9月の関ケ原の戦いでは東軍に属した。
sen.e: He joined the East squad at the Battle of Sekigahara in September, 1600.
He joined the East squad at the Battle of Sekigahara in September, 1600.
He joined the East squad at the Battle of Sekigahara in September, 1600.

sen.j: 関ヶ原の合戦前の岐阜城攻略では黒田長政・藤堂高虎と共に大垣城から岐阜城へ向かう西軍を河渡川で殲滅した。
sen.e: He exterminated the West squad, who was on the way from Ogaki-jo Castle to Gifu-jo Castle, at the Godo-gawa River together with Nagamasa KURODA and Takatora TODO, when he was capturing Gifu-jo Castle before the Battle of Sekigahara.

He exterminated the West squad, who was on the way from Ogaki-jo Castle to Gifu-jo Castle, at the Godo-gawa River together with Nagamasa KURODA and Takatora TODO, when he was capturing Gifu-jo Castle before the Battle of Sekigahara.

He exterminated the West squad, who was on the way from Ogaki-jo Castle to Gifu-jo Castle, at the Godo-gawa River together with Nagamasa KURODA and Takatora TODO, when he was capturing Gifu-jo Castle before the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: この際、石田三成の配下の杉江勘兵衛は、吉政の家臣である辻勘兵衛重勝により討ち取られ戦死している。
sen.e: At that time, a vassal of Mitsunari ISHIDA, Kanbe SUGIE was killed by a vassal of him, Kanbe Shigekatsu TSUJI.
At that time, a vassal of Mitsunari ISHIDA, Kanbe SUGIE was killed by a vassal of his, Kanbe Shigekatsu TSUJI.
At that time, a vassal of Mitsunari ISHIDA, Kanbe SUGIE was killed by a vassal of his, Kanbe Shigekatsu TSUJI.

sen.j: これにより、三成は戦意を喪失したという記述がある。
sen.e: Mitsunari is said to have lost his fighting spirit because of that.
Mitsunari is said to have lost his fighting spirit because of that.
Mitsunari is said to have lost his fighting spirit because of that.

sen.j: 大垣城を吉政が攻略する際、大砲を撃つ時は城の者に事前通告したという記述がおあん物語にある。
sen.e: According to "The tale of Oan", he gave an advance notice to fire a cannon to people in Ogaki-jo Castle while he was attacking the Castle.
According to "The tale of Oan", he gave an advance notice before firing a cannon at people in Ogaki-jo Castle while he was attacking the Castle.
According to "The tale of Oan", he gave an advance notice before firing a cannon at people in Ogaki-jo Castle while he was attacking the Castle.

sen.j: またおあんらの女子が城を逃れる際に見逃したという事実がある。
sen.e: He also overlooked women, including Oan, running away from the castle.
He also overlooked women, including Oan, running away from the castle.
He also overlooked women, including Oan, running away from the castle.

sen.j: このように実際に戦闘に加わらないものに対し、格別の配慮をするのが田中吉政の城攻めであるとされている。
sen.e: Thus, he is said to have been thoughtful of people who were not participants in a battle as he attacked a castle.
Thus, he is said to have been thoughtful of people who were not participants in a battle as he attacked a castle.
Thus, he is said to have been thoughtful of people who were not participants in a battle as he attacked a castle.

sen.j: また西軍の最前線で戦った明石全登（田中吉政の娘婿という説がある)の逃走を、合戦後に黒田長政（明石全登の親族)と共に手助けをしたとされている。
sen.e: He, together with Nagamasa KURODA (a relative of Takenori AKASHI), is also considered to have helped Takenori AKASHI (a theory says he was a Yoshimasa's son-in-law), who battled at the front of the West squad, to run away after the battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: He, together with Nagamasa KURODA (a relative of Takenori AKASHI), is also considered to have helped Takenori AKASHI (a theory says he was a Yoshimasa's son-in-law), who battled at the front of the West squad, to escape after the battle.

He, together with Nagamasa KURODA (a relative of Takenori AKASHI), is also considered to have helped Takenori AKASHI (a theory says he was a Yoshimasa's son-in-law), who battled at the front of the West squad, to escape after the battle.

sen.j: （実際は黒田孝高の没後、黒田長政がキリスト教を禁教したので、田中忠政を頼ったという。)
sen.e: Actually, Takenori AKASHI turned to Tadamasa TANAKA because Nagamasa KURODA banned Christianity after Yoshitaka KURODA's death.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Actually, Takenori AKASHI turned to Tadamasa TANAKA because Nagamasa KURODA banned Christianity after Yoshitaka KURODA's death.
Actually, Takenori AKASHI turned to Tadamasa TANAKA because Nagamasa KURODA banned Christianity after Yoshitaka KURODA's death.

tit.e: After the victory of the East squad
After the victory of the East squad
After the victory of the East squad

sen.j: 東軍勝利後、三成の居城佐和山城を宮部長煕と共に搦手から突入して落城させる
sen.e: After the East squad's victory, Yoshimasa broke into Mitsunari's Sawayama-jo Castle from its backdoor together with Nagahiro MIYABE and captured the castle.
After the East squad's victory, Yoshimasa broke into Mitsunari's Sawayama-jo Castle from its backdoor together with Nagahiro MIYABE and captured the castle.
After the East squad's victory, Yoshimasa broke into Mitsunari's Sawayama-jo Castle from its backdoor together with Nagahiro MIYABE and captured the castle.

sen.j: 宮部 長煕は宮部長房の諱である。
sen.e: Nagahiro MIYABE was a real name of Nagafusa MIYABE.
Nagahiro MIYABE was a real name of Nagafusa MIYABE.
Nagahiro MIYABE was a real name of Nagafusa MIYABE.

sen.j: ここに旧主家の宮部長房と旧家臣の田中吉政の関係がみてとれる。
sen.e: The relationship between the former lord, Nagafusa MIYABE and the former vassal, Yoshimasa TANAKA can be found in the story of the attack.
The relationship between the former lord, Nagafusa MIYABE and the former vassal, Yoshimasa TANAKA can be found in the story of the attack.
The relationship between the former lord, Nagafusa MIYABE and the former vassal, Yoshimasa TANAKA can be found in the story of the attack.

sen.j: すなわち突入の指示は宮部長房の発したものであろう。
sen.e: That is to say, Nagafusa MIYABE must have ordered to break into the castle.
That is to say, Nagafusa MIYABE must have ordered to break into the castle.
That is to say, Nagafusa MIYABE must have ordered to break into the castle.

sen.j: この「城攻め方法」は田中吉政が指示したにしては、あまりに稚拙であると考えられる。
sen.e: The strategy of attacking the castle was too poor a tactic to be thought Yashimasa directed it.
The strategy of attacking the castle was too poor a tactic to be thought that Yashimasa had directed it.
The strategy of attacking the castle was too poor a tactic to be thought that Yashimasa had directed it.

sen.j: なお佐和山城攻めは寝返った武将、小早川秀秋や宮部長房らが命じられたものであった。
sen.e: Incidentally, Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA, who went over to the East squad, and Nagafusa MIYABE were ordered to capture Sawayama-jo Castle.
Incidentally, Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA, who went over to the East squad, and Nagafusa MIYABE were ordered to capture Sawayama-jo Castle.
Incidentally, Hideaki KOBAYAKAWA, who went over to the East squad, and Nagafusa MIYABE were ordered to capture Sawayama-jo Castle.

sen.j: 三成の兄と父が切腹する条件で開城して城の者の助命するという内容で講和の交渉中に、佐和山城に突入し多くの死者を出したわけではある。
sen.e: During a negotiation of making peace under the terms that the castle would surrender and the lives of people in the castle would be spared in exchange for hara-kiri of Mitsunari's older brother and father, Yoshimasa's forces broke into the castle and it brought many deaths.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: During a negotiation of making peace under the terms that the castle would surrender and the lives of people in the castle would be spared in exchange for the hara-kiri of Mitsunari's older brother and father, Yoshimasa's forces broke into the castle and it brought many deaths.

During a negotiation of making peace under the terms that the castle would surrender and the lives of people in the castle would be spared in exchange for the seppuku of Mitsunari's older brother and father, Yoshimasa's forces broke into the castle and it brought many deaths.

sen.j: 突入の指示を現場の指揮官でない、吉政が発した可能性は少ないであろう。
sen.e: There is a bare possibility that Yoshimasa, who was not a commander on the scene, ordered to break into the castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There is a bare possibility that Yoshimasa, who was not a commander on the scene, ordered to break into the castle.
There is a bare possibility that Yoshimasa, who was not a commander on the scene, ordered to break into the castle.

sen.j: 「寛政重修諸家譜」によれば、吉政は搦手（北側)から攻め込み、篭城軍の抵抗が激しいので、水ノ手郭に金堀を潜入させ内部を攪乱、落城させることに成功したとある。
sen.e: According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu", he broke into the castle from the backdoor (on the north side) but faced a violent resistance of the besieged force, so he infiltrated Mizunotekuruwa (a compound of a castle in charge of drawing water) with miners to cause an inner disturbance, then he captured the castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu", he broke into the castle from the backdoor (on the north side) but faced a violent resistance of the besieged force, so he infiltrated Mizunotekuruwa (a compound of a castle in charge of drawing water) with miners to cause an inner disturbance, then he captured the castle.

According to "Kansei Choshu Shokafu", he broke into the castle from the backdoor (on the north side) but faced a violent resistance of the besieged force, so he infiltrated Mizunotekuruwa (a compound of a castle in charge of drawing water) with miners to cause an inner disturbance, then he captured the castle.

sen.j: 一説にあるような、あっけない落城ではないとされている。
sen.e: This was not an easy capture as one theory says.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This was not an easy capture as one theory says.
This was not an easy capture as one theory says.

sen.j: 家康は吉政に、関ヶ原の戦い以前から、佐和山城周辺や、逃走経路を調査させ、三成の捕縛も直接指示していた。
sen.e: Ieyasu ordered Yoshimasa to investigate around Sawayama-jo Castle and look for possible escape routes before the battle of Sekigahara and directed the capture of Mitsunari immediately.
Ieyasu ordered Yoshimasa to investigate around Sawayama-jo Castle and look for possible escape routes before the battle of Sekigahara and directed the capture of Mitsunari immediately.
Ieyasu ordered Yoshimasa to investigate around Sawayama-jo Castle and look for possible escape routes before the battle of Sekigahara and directed the capture of Mitsunari immediately.

sen.j: 家康は後に三成に墓石を作らせず、また三成の先祖の墓石をすべて地中に埋めているほど三成を恨んでいた。
sen.e: Ieyasu had a grudge against Mitsunari so much that he didn't allow Mitsunari to have a gravestone and buried all gravestones of Mitsunari's ancestors.
Ieyasu had such a grudge against Mitsunari that he didn't allow Mitsunari to have a gravestone and buried all gravestones of Mitsunari's ancestors.
Ieyasu had such a grudge against Mitsunari that he did not allow Mitsunari to have a gravestone and buried all gravestones of Mitsunari's ancestors.

sen.j: したがって佐和山城への突入も家康の直接の指示だった可能性が大きい。
sen.e: Therefore, the order to break into Sawayama-jo Castle was likely to be given by Ieyasu.
Therefore, the order to break into Sawayama-jo Castle was likely to have been given by Ieyasu.
Therefore, the order to break into Sawayama-jo Castle was likely to have been given by Ieyasu.

sen.j: 吉政は伊吹山中で逃亡中の石田三成を捕縛する大功を挙げた。
sen.e: Yoshimasa achieved the capture of Mitsunari as he tried to escape in Mt.Ibuki.
sen.cmt: ウェブ上の記事と異なります。前セルの文と繋がりませんので、文頭に「吉政は」を補いました。
sen.e: Yoshimasa achieved the capture of Mitsunari as he tried to escape in Mt.Ibuki.
Yoshimasa achieved the capture of Mitsunari as he tried to escape in Mt.Ibuki.

sen.j: 実際に捕縛に当たったのは、田中伝左衛門・沢田少右衛門である。
sen.e: Indeed, Denzaemon TANAKA and Shoemon SAWADA were the soldiers who captured Mitsunari.
Indeed, Denzaemon TANAKA and Shoemon SAWADA were the soldiers who captured Mitsunari.
Indeed, Denzaemon TANAKA and Shoemon SAWADA were the soldiers who captured Mitsunari.

sen.j: 伝えられているところによると、三成は腹痛で病んでいたが、医師のすすめる薬は拒否した。
sen.e: It is said that Mitsunari suffered from a stomachache but rejected doctor's medicine so, after careful consideration, Yoshimasa offered Chinese chive rice porridge under the pretext that it worked for his health, then Mitsunari ate it.

It is said that Mitsunari suffered from a stomachache but rejected doctor's medicine. So, after careful consideration, Yoshimasa offered Chinese chive rice porridge under the pretext that it worked for his health, and Mitsunari ate it.
It is said that Mitsunari suffered from a stomachache but rejected doctor's medicine.
sen.cmt: ☆一原文一訳文の例外対処原文を分割、若干の変更trans2で、英文が２文になっているため、原文を分割の上、2文目を次のセルに移しました。

sen.j: そのため、吉政は熟慮の上、健康に良いという理由付けをしニラ粥を勧めたので三成はそれを食した。
sen.e: So, after careful consideration, Yoshimasa offered Chinese chive rice porridge under the pretext that it worked for his health, and Mitsunari ate it.
sen.cmt: ☆一原文一訳文の例外対処原文を分割

sen.j: 吉政に会った三成は太閤から給わった脇差しを吉政に授けた（寸延短刀 石田貞宗：東京国立博物館蔵)。
sen.e: Mitsunari gave Yoshimasa a short sword which Mitsunari was granted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (over-30.3 cm-long short sword called Sadamune ISHIDA, a property of Tokyo National Museum).
Mitsunari gave Yoshimasa a short sword which Mitsunari was granted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (over-30.3 cm-long short sword called Sadamune ISHIDA, a property of Tokyo National Museum).
Mitsunari gave Yoshimasa a short sword which Mitsunari was granted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (over-30.3 cm-long short sword called Sadamune ISHIDA, a property of Tokyo National Museum).

sen.j: 手厚くもてなされた礼であると言われている。
sen.e: It was recognition in return for Yoshimasa's hospitality.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: It was in recognition of Yoshimasa's hospitality.
It was in recognition of Yoshimasa's hospitality.

sen.j: （三成も捕縛される時、「他の者よりはお前に捕らえられた方がいい」という旨の発言をしたという)。
sen.e: (Mitsunari may have said something to the effect that he would rather be caught by Yoshimasa than others.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: (Mitsunari may have said something to the effect that he would rather be caught by Yoshimasa than others.)
(Mitsunari may have said something to the effect that he would rather be caught by Yoshimasa than others.)
sen.cmt: 表記の修正をしました。

sen.j: 戦後これらの勲功が認められて、筑後国一国柳川城32万石を与えられ国主となった。
sen.e: After the battle, his achievements were recognized and he was given 320,000 koku of Yanagawa-jo Castle in Chikugo Province to become Kokushu (a feudal lord having his own domain).
After the battle, his achievements were recognized and he was given 320,000 koku of Yanagawa-jo Castle in Chikugo Province to become Kokushu (a feudal lord having his own domain).
After the battle, his achievements were recognized and he was given 320,000 koku of Yanagawa-jo Castle in Chikugo Province to become Kokushu (a feudal lord having his own domain).

tit.e: In the time of the lord of Chikugo Province
In the time of the lord of Chikugo Province
In the time of the lord of Chikugo Province

sen.j: 蒲池氏が領主だった頃から柳川は「水都」といわれたが、吉政は柳川に交通のための水路や稲作のための用水路を整備し近代的な街作りをした。
sen.e: Yanagawa was called "the capital of water" since the Kamachi clan ruled there, and Yoshimasa developed Yanagawa to be a modern town with waterways for transportation and irrigation canals for rice cropping.
sen.cmt: 原文が不自然のため「得意と」を削除しました。
sen.e: Yanagawa was called "the capital of water" since the Kamachi clan ruled there, and Yoshimasa developed Yanagawa to be a modern town with waterways for transportation and irrigation canals for rice cropping.

Yanagawa was called "the capital of water" since the Kamachi clan ruled there, and Yoshimasa developed Yanagawa to be a modern town with waterways for transportation and irrigation canals for rice cropping.

sen.j: 水路以外にも柳川と久留米を結ぶ田中街道や柳川と八女を結ぶ街道など陸路の整備にも力をいれた。
sen.e: In addition to waterways, he focused on the improvement of land routes such as Tanaka-kaido Road which connected Yanagawa and Kurume, and a road which connected Yanagawa and Yame.
In addition to waterways, he focused on the improvement of land routes such as Tanaka-kaido Road which connected Yanagawa and Kurume, and a road which connected Yanagawa and Yame.
In addition to waterways, he focused on the improvement of land routes such as Tanaka-kaido Road which connected Yanagawa and Kurume, and a road which connected Yanagawa and Yame.

sen.j: また、収入の増加を目指して有明海の干拓にも熱心に取り組んだ。
sen.e: Moreover, he worked hard to reclaim the Sea of Ariake to increase revenue.
Moreover, he worked hard to reclaim the Sea of Ariake to increase revenue.
Moreover, he worked hard to reclaim the Sea of Ariake to increase revenue.

sen.j: また、吉政は岡崎城主のころからキリスト教に対して寛容で、宣教師たちから西洋の知識を積極的に学んだ。
sen.e: Yoshimasa was lenient with Christianity since he was the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle and had actively learned the western knowledge from missionaries.
Yoshimasa was lenient with Christianity since he was the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle and had actively studied western thought from missionaries.
Yoshimasa was lenient with Christianity since he was the lord of Okazaki-jo Castle and had actively studied western thought from missionaries.

sen.j: 領内のキリスト教信者を保護し、みずからも帰依したと言う。
sen.e: He protected his domain's Christians and became a believer in Christianity.
He protected his domain's Christians and became a believer in Christianity.
He protected his domain's Christians and became a believer in Christianity.

sen.j: 洗礼名はパルトロメヨ（バルトロメオ、またバルトロマイ〔Bartolomeo,〕)。
sen.e: His baptismal name was Bartolomeo.
His baptismal name was Bartholomew.
His baptismal name was Bartholomew.

sen.j: 吉政は浄土系宗派の仏教徒で、菩提寺である真教寺、金戒光明寺、善導寺など浄土系仏教寺院を含む、多くの仏教寺院の再興（改修・寺町の造営など)にも力を尽くし、仏教の保護にも努めた。
sen.e: He was also a Jodo (Pure Land) sect Buddhist, so he concentrated his energy on restoration (repair and construction of temple districts) of many Buddhist temples including his family temple: Shinkyo-ji Temple, Konkai Komyo-ji Temple, Zendo-ji Temple and other Jodo sect temples, and endeavored to protect Buddhism.

He was also a Jodo (Pure Land) sect Buddhist, so he concentrated his energy on restoration (repair and construction of temple districts) of many Buddhist temples including his family temple: Shinkyo-ji Temple, Konkai Komyo-ji Temple, Zendo-ji Temple and other Jodo sect temples, and endeavored to protect Buddhism.

He was also a Jodo (Pure Land) sect Buddhist, so he concentrated his energy on restoration (repair and construction of temple districts) of many Buddhist temples including his family temple: Shinkyo-ji Temple, Konkai Komyo-ji Temple, Zendo-ji Temple and other Jodo sect temples, and endeavored to protect Buddhism.

sen.j: ただし、岡崎においては、在任期間が10年程度と短いこともあり、岡崎城下整備のために、吉政に移転を迫られたり、所領を召し上げられた寺社が多くある（特に徳川家と関係の薄い寺社)。
sen.e: However, in Okazaki, where he ruled for only ten years, many temples and shrines (especially, those who had little relationship with the Tokugawa family) were forced to move or had their territory confiscated in efforts to improve Okazaki-jo Castle town.

However, in Okazaki, where he ruled for only ten years, many temples and shrines (especially, those who had little relationship with the Tokugawa family) were forced to move or had their territory confiscated in efforts to improve Okazaki-jo Castle town.

However, in Okazaki, where he ruled for only ten years, many temples and shrines (especially, those who had little relationship with the Tokugawa family) were forced to move or had their territory confiscated in efforts to improve Okazaki-jo Castle town.

sen.j: 『萬徳寺縁起』では吉政の寺社弾圧の苛性を伝えている。
sen.e: "The origin of Mantoku-ji Temple" describes Yoshimasa's oppression of temples and shrines.
sen.cmt: 「苛性」は「苛政」だと思われます。
sen.e: "The origin of Mantoku-ji Temple" describes Yoshimasa's oppression of temples and shrines.
"The origin of Mantoku-ji Temple" describes Yoshimasa's oppression of temples and shrines.

sen.j: 慶長14年に京都伏見で吉政が没し、後嗣となった田中忠政が男子を残さぬまま死去したために、元和6年（1620年)に改易されてしまった。
sen.e: Yoshimasa died in Fishimi, Kyoto in 1609 and his successor, Tadamasa TANAKA died without having a son, so the Tanaka family forfeited its rank and properties in 1620.
Yoshimasa died in Fushimi, Kyoto in 1609 and his successor, Tadamasa TANAKA died without having a son, so the Tanaka family forfeited its rank and properties in 1620.
Yoshimasa died in Fushimi, Kyoto in 1609 and his successor, Tadamasa TANAKA died without having a son, so the Tanaka family forfeited its rank and properties in 1620.

sen.j: これは忠政がキリスト教を保護したのが一因とされている。
sen.e: Tadamasa's protection of Christianity is considered to have contributed to this.
Tadamasa's protection of Christianity is considered to have contributed to this.
Tadamasa's protection of Christianity is considered to have contributed to this.

sen.j: なお忠政は曹洞宗に改宗している。
sen.e: By the way, Tadamasa was converted to Soto sect.
By the way, Tadamasa was converted to Soto sect.
By the way, Tadamasa was converted to Soto sect.

sen.j: 久留米の寺町にある真教寺（浄土真宗)が一時菩提寺であったことがあった（墓所はない)。
sen.e: Shinkyo-ji Temple (Jodo Shin sect [the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism]) in a temple district in Kurume was temporary his family temple (but not grave).
Shinkyo-ji Temple (Jodo Shin sect [the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism]) in a temple district in Kurume was his temporary family temple (but not grave).
Shinkyo-ji Temple (Jodo Shin sect [the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism]) in a temple district in Kurume was his temporary family temple (but not grave).

sen.j: 墓所は東京駒込の吉祥寺 (東京都文京区)（曹洞宗)、京都黒谷の浄土宗大本山金戒光明寺塔頭龍光院 (京都市左京区)（浄土宗)墓地、柳川市の真勝寺 (柳川市)（浄土真宗菩提寺)、久留米市の善導寺 (久留米市)（浄土宗大本山)などにある。
sen.e: The Tanaka family's graves were in Kichijo-ji Temple (Soto sect) in Komagome, Tokyo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo); a head temple of Jodo sect, Kokai Komyo-ji Temple's sub-temple, Ryuko-in Temple (Jodo sect) in Kurodani, Kyoto (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City); Shinsho-ji Temple (Jodoshin sect) in Yanagawa City; Zendo-ji Temple (a head temple of Jodo sect) in Kurume City.

The Tanaka family's graves were in Kichijo-ji Temple (Soto sect) in Komagome, Tokyo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo); a head temple of Jodo sect, Kokai Komyo-ji Temple's sub-temple, Ryuko-in Temple (Jodo sect) in Kurodani, Kyoto (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City); Shinsho-ji Temple (Jodoshin sect) in Yanagawa City; Zendo-ji Temple (a head temple of Jodo sect) in Kurume City.

The Tanaka family's graves were in Kichijo-ji Temple (Soto sect) in Komagome, Tokyo (Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo); a head temple of Jodo sect, Kokai Komyo-ji Temple's sub-temple, Ryuko-in Temple (Jodo sect) in Kurodani, Kyoto (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City); Shinsho-ji Temple (Jodoshin sect) in Yanagawa City; Zendo-ji Temple (a head temple of Jodo sect) in Kurume City.

sen.j: 傍系の親族は他家の家臣となることなどで家系を存続させている。
sen.e: The collateral descendants kept its family line by being vassals of other lords.
The collateral descendants continued the family line by being vassals of other lords.
The collateral descendants continued the family line by being vassals of other lords.

sen.j: 田中吉政の家紋は複数あり、その一つは近江八幡に在任中、八幡社（日牟禮八幡宮）より賜ったという説もある左三つ巴で、関ヶ原の合戦時にも旗頭として使用している。
sen.e: Yoshimasa TANAKA had several crests and one of them was "hidari misudomoe", which he is said to have been granted by Hachiman-sha shrine during his rule in Omihachiman, used as emblem on his flag at the Battle of Sekigahara.

Yoshimasa TANAKA had several crests and one of them was "hidari misudomoe", which he is said to have been granted by Hachiman-sha shrine during his rule in Omihachiman, used as emblem on his flag at the Battle of Sekigahara.

Yoshimasa TANAKA had several crests and one of them was "hidari mitsudomoe", which he is said to have been granted by Hachiman-sha shrine (Himure Hachiman-gu shrine) during his rule in Omihachiman, used as emblem on his flag at the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: また釘貫紋（九城抜きともいう：城攻めの名手を表す）も多く用いている、一つ目結紋と同じ形なので先祖が佐々木氏関係者だったことの証拠とされる。
sen.e: He often used "Kuginuki-mon" (or "Kujonuki" which means an expert of attacking a castle) and it is regarded as proof that his ancestor had a relationship with the Sasaki clan because it is the same shape as "Hitotsumeyui-mon".
